docs.abstract: The Italian company’s latest offering is a reimagining of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with an all-black cast.
docs.snippet: The Italian company’s latest offering is a reimagining of “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” with an all-black cast.
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a muggy afternoon in May, in a heavily guarded studio hidden along a nondescript industrial North London back road, RuPaul, the actor, drag queen and TV personality, was holding court inside a padded box, wearing a resplendent scarlet red ball gown from which oversize playing cards tumbled from the voluminous skirt. Inches away, the actor Djimon Hounsou stood staring, shirtless, sporting a gold crown and pinstripe trousers.

headline.main: What the 2018 Pirelli Calendar Says About Race
headline.print_headline: Not Just Recording History, but Making It, Too

docs.abstract: The political investigation ensnared a senator and seven congressmen. He also negotiated the surrender of the escaped killer of Kitty Genovese.
docs.snippet: The political investigation ensnared a senator and seven congressmen. He also negotiated the surrender of the escaped killer of Kitty Genovese.
docs.lead_paragraph: Neil J. Welch, a maverick F.B.I. official who helped mastermind the political corruption sting operation that ensnared a senator and six congressmen and negotiated the surrender of the escaped killer of Kitty Genovese, died on June 29 in Omaha. He was 90.

headline.main: Neil Welch, F.B.I. Mastermind in Abscam Sting Operation, Dies at 90
headline.print_headline: Neil Welch, 90; Led Abscam Sting Operation

docs.abstract: Mr. Simpson will be released in October after spending nine years in prison on charges stemming from an armed robbery.
docs.snippet: Mr. Simpson will be released in October after spending nine years in prison on charges stemming from an armed robbery.
docs.lead_paragraph: He has tumbled in the public eye from revered football hero and actor, to reviled wife abuser and murder defendant, to indebted and hapless convicted robber, but O.J. Simpson went before a Nevada parole board on Thursday flashing his usual self-assurance, telling the board that he was “a good guy” and asserting, implausibly, “I basically have spent a conflict-free life.”

headline.main: O.J. Simpson Wins Parole, Claiming He Has Led a ‘Conflict-Free Life’
headline.print_headline: Claiming a ‘Conflict-Free Life,’ Simpson Gets Parole in Robbery

docs.abstract: A reader responds to a misstated metaphor, an author defends his work and more.
docs.snippet: A reader responds to a misstated metaphor, an author defends his work and more.

docs.abstract: Kaepernick is still not signed to an N.F.L. team, and everyone has an opinion why. The newest one comes from the former star quarterback, who thinks Kaepernick should ditch his Afro.
docs.snippet: Kaepernick is still not signed to an N.F.L. team, and everyone has an opinion why. The newest one comes from the former star quarterback, who thinks Kaepernick should ditch his Afro.
docs.lead_paragraph: Does Colin Kaepernick want a job as a quarterback in the N.F.L.? Michael Vick said he thought a haircut would help.

headline.main: Michael Vick’s Advice for Unemployed Colin Kaepernick: Cut Your Hair
headline.print_headline: Vick’s Advice to Kaepernick: Get a Haircut

docs.abstract: I am a minister, and black lives matter to me. I am not confident they matter to the convention.
docs.snippet: I am a minister, and black lives matter to me. I am not confident they matter to the convention.
docs.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The first time I was called a nigger to my face was by a fellow camper at a Southern Baptist Convention retreat near Oklahoma City. I was 13, and it was 1995. Devastated, I complained to a counselor who suggested I pray for the ability to turn the other cheek. Since then, I have done just that and more: I’ve been an ordained minister in the convention for almost a decade.

headline.main: Why I’m Leaving the Southern Baptist Convention
headline.print_headline: I’m Done Being a Southern Baptist

docs.abstract: Fifty years ago, starting on July 12, 1967, racial tensions in Newark exploded. Here are some recollections of that time and how it has shaped the present.
docs.snippet: Fifty years ago, starting on July 12, 1967, racial tensions in Newark exploded. Here are some recollections of that time and how it has shaped the present.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The fuse that ignited this city — violent clashes with the police, gunfire, flames from burning buildings — was a rumor. Word spread that a black cabdriver had been killed inside a police precinct house. It was not true — the driver had been arrested and injured.

headline.main: Five Days of Unrest That Shaped, and Haunted, Newark

byline.original: By Rick Rojas and Khorri Atkinson

docs.abstract: Great reads around the web, from Julie Bloom, Gina Lamb and others.
docs.snippet: Great reads around the web, from Julie Bloom, Gina Lamb and others.
docs.lead_paragraph: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

docs.abstract: As the global spotlight on the nation’s domestic policies has dimmed, lawyers for dissidents increasingly face a terrible choice: acquiescence or imprisonment.
docs.snippet: As the global spotlight on the nation’s domestic policies has dimmed, lawyers for dissidents increasingly face a terrible choice: acquiescence or imprisonment.
docs.lead_paragraph: Liang Xiaojun had just finished breakfast when he received the first instant message: His friends were disappearing from their homes and offices. By itself, this news was unremarkable. As a human rights lawyer in China, Liang had come to accept that periodic spasms of repression were an unavoidable risk of his profession. He also had grown intimately familiar with the rituals of pressure and coercion by which China kept its dissidents in line — the meetings over tea with government minders, the frequent check-ins from the judicial bureau, the police harassment. But on the morning of July 10, 2015, Liang knew that something far graver was underway.

headline.main: ‘Flee at Once’: China’s Besieged Human Rights Lawyers

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

docs.abstract: History matters in the South. But there was something particularly instructive about seeing the region’s Civil Rights past through the eyes of visiting high school students.
docs.snippet: History matters in the South. But there was something particularly instructive about seeing the region’s Civil Rights past through the eyes of visiting high school students.
docs.lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala., — In the lobby of the antebellum St. James Hotel, on a desolate street in Selma, Ala., around the corner from the Edmund Pettus Bridge, there’s a photograph of a resident ghost.

headline.main: A Tour of Ghosts, History and the South’s Civil Rights Past
